title: 112_hr1638
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dollar Bill Act of 2011". Congress acknowledges that the power to regulate the value of money was delegated to the Federal Reserve System in 1913. The value of the US dollar has significantly decreased compared to gold, oil, and other currencies. The Federal Reserve System was given the power to regulate the value of US and foreign currency in 1913. The value of the US dollar has dropped significantly compared to gold, oil, and other currencies, leading to instability and uncertainty. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has not been able to provide a stable and reliable value for the US dollar. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has not been able to produce a stable and reliable value for the United States dollar, leading to economic slowdown and reduced earnings for American workers. The unstable dollar has negative effects on the economy, including increasing the cost of capital, reducing real earnings for workers, and diminishing the value of financial assets and retirement accounts. An unstable dollar reduces the real value of financial assets, pension plans, and retirement accounts for American workers, damaging the economic and political standing of the United States in the world community. It also creates anxiety and uncertainty in financial markets. SEC. 3. DIRECTIVES TO THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS OF THE FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is directed to make the value of the U.S. dollar equal to the price of gold on the COMEX exchange and maintain it at that level. They are prohibited from using indirect open market operations to regulate the dollar's value. This directive aims to promote stable and effective financial markets. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is directed to regulate the value of the U.S. dollar to match the price of gold on the COMEX exchange. They are not allowed to use indirect open market operations for this purpose. This directive is aimed at maintaining stable and effective financial markets. Effective January 1, 2011, entities can expense 100 percent of capital investment for tax purposes in the year of investment. The Congressional Budget Office will calculate the impact of tax changes on Federal revenues on a present value basis, similar to the Social Security Trustees. This includes considering the acceleration of first-year expensing of capital investment and the historical trends of business capital investments. The impact of tax changes on Federal revenues will be calculated by the Congressional Budget Office in a manner similar to the Social Security Trustees. This calculation will consider the acceleration of first-year expensing of capital investment and the higher returns historically earned by businesses on their capital investments. SEC. 6 of the Act states that in case of conflict with the Full Employment and Balanced Growth Act of 1978, the provisions of this Act will prevail. SEC. 7 removes the Federal Reserve Bank's authority to pay earnings on reserves. Section 19(b)(12) of the Federal Reserve Act is amended to remove the Federal Reserve Bank's authority to pay earnings on reserves.
